awd_titl_txt: MRI: Development of a Miniaturized Molecular Beam Epitaxy Setup for Direct Printing of Quantum Circuits
awd_abstract_narration:
This Major Research Instrumentation (MRI) grant will support the development of a nanoscale deposition tool – a miniaturized molecular beam epitaxy (MBE) system – for direct fabrication of nanoscale structures for quantum applications. As the era of quantum engineering emerges, there is a pressing need to rapidly design, prototype, and test nanoscale structures for quantum information processing. This is critical not only to the investigation of fundamental questions in quantum information sciences, but also to the development of quantum sensors, quantum computing, and quantum networking. Current technologies separate material synthesis and nanoscale engineering.  To enable more rapid development, researchers will pursue an innovative design based on nanoscale scanning probe technologies and develop a deposition tool that combines advanced synthesis and nanofabrication in one step. This instrument will have the following impacts: i) facilitate rapid development of quantum technologies; ii) develop a versatile tool to serve the broad quantum research and engineering community at the University of Chicago; iii) promote education and outreach at the graduate, undergraduate, and high school level. Outreach programs will engage the surrounding community in the Chicago South area. The investigators will allocate 40% of machine usage to the broader quantum research community at the University of Chicago, which will serve as an intellectual hub for training future quantum scientists. 

The team includes experts on nanoscale materials science, microelectronics, quantum sensing, quantum computing, and quantum information.  It has the goal of developing a miniaturized MBE system. Traditional MBE is a state-of-the-art deposition tool to produce wafer-scale thin films; nanofabrication such as photo- or electron-beam-lithography is used as the second step to engineer the nanoscale structures and devices. Supported by this MRI grant, the investigators shrink the lateral scale of deposition to tens of nanometers. This is achieved by customizing a scanning probe into a nano nozzle, which is integrated into a commercial scanning tunneling microscopy system. This new tool is developed in a dedicated laboratory space at the University of Chicago, with established microscopy and spectroscopy tools available to characterize the structures fabricated by the miniaturized MBE system. This instrument will enable research in a number of new scientific areas including but not limited to: 1) two-dimensional superconducting quantum devices based on nanoscale superconductor deposition; 2) delta doping of rare earth elements in oxide materials to host individual to few-body entangled quantum bits; 3) hybrid quantum sensors composed of rare-earth oxide islands and nitrogen-vacancy centers. This will be a field-defining development which aims at expediting the investigation of fundamental quantum phenomena and quantum technology developments.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering
org_div_long_name: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual merit: This project aims at building a miniaturized 3D printer for quantum devices - devices that manipulate information in revolutionary ways that lead to secure communication, precise prediction of material properties, and drug discoveries. The general idea is to feed molecular beams into nanoscale confinement, realizing a spray-printing gun which draws structures at a precision of one millionth to one billionth of a meter. In the NSF award period of 2020-2024, Principal Investigator Yang and the team developed 3 generations of this 3D printer.

Generation 1: the device structure is engraved in a shadow mask and the shadow mask is directly placed in the molecular beams to define the printed device. This technology leads to a printing resolution of 40 millionth of a meter (see image: Generation-1 3D printer of quantum devices). The printed device using an unconventional superconductor, iron selenide, is reported in Ref. [1].

Generation 2: the device structure is dynamically and programmably printed using a single nozzle, with a resolution of 40-50 millionth of a meter (Generation-2 3D printer of quantum devices).

Generation 3: three nano-nozzles are implemented together with a nano-positioned sample stage, enabling a best-effort printing resolution of 210 billionth of a meter near the feature edges (Generation-3 3D printer of quantum devices). In particular, a special thermal insulator is designed to separate the hot substrate at 500 degrees Celsius and the nano-positioner at room temperature [2]. A machine learning algorithm is also developed to enable autonomous material deposition [3].

The principal investigator and his team achieved the intellectual merit objectives of 1) designing, procuring, and setting up the miniaturized molecular beam epitaxy system - the equivalent of a 3D printer of quantum circuits, 2) conducting customization to develop single-source nano nozzles, 3) fabricating superconducting circuitry based on simple superconductors and iron selenide unconventional superconductors, and 4) developing the key technologies for fabricating oxide quantum sensors. Moreover, the team developed a new kind of thermal insulator with a record-low thermal conductivity, which has a profound impact in aerospace engineering. The team also developed a new artificial intelligence method to enable fully autonomous thin film deposition.

Broader impacts: We have leveraged the development of the state-of-the-art instrumentation, and established the connection between the project and the quantum science and engineering community within and beyond the University of Chicago.

1. By growing and printing superconducting materials, we initiated scientific collaborations on superconducting quantum bits, circuit elements, and more devices. The instrument has reinforced the quantum materials science community at the University of Chicago.

2. We have successfully recruited and trained under-represented minority students, including 1 PhD student, 1 undergraduate student, and 1 high school intern student.

3. Principal Investigator Yang utilized the research results in his teaching of a new undergraduate course "Science of Materials," and a graduate course "Electronic and Quantum Materials for Technology." Moreover, Yang broadened the participation of under-represented minority students in Chicago public schools by introducing superconductivity in the UChicago Quantum Quickstart program, which is an annual 1-week workshop for high school students. Yang and team regularly presented a superconducting quantum levitation demonstration in an annual science outreach program "Physics with a Bang" which engaged the public in the Chicago South Side.

Through rigorous education and outreach efforts, Yang and team have achieved the broader impacts objectives: 1) after the equipment completion, allocate 40% machine time to the broader UChicago quantum community; 2) promote graduate and undergraduate training especially for those from under-represented minority groups; 3) promote connections with high school students.

Publications:

[1] Yan et al. Rev. Sci. Instrum. 92, 113907 (2021)

[2] Rokni et al. arXiv 2411.18698

[3] Zheng et al. arXiv 2411.18721


Last Modified: 12/28/2024
Modified by: Shuolong Yang

    Generation-2 3D printer of quantum devices
  • Third-generation 3D printer of quantum devices, featuring 3 nozzles, a thermal insulator, and an edge resolution of 210 billionth of a meter.
    Shuolong Yang

    Generation-3 3D printer of quantum devices
